Line 40: Line 40:
===1 February===
===1 February===
â
A disused building at the [[University of Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] was occupied and re-opened as the [[Free Hetherington]] anti-cuts space. It has since attracted much controversy due to heavy-handed attempts to evict the students, staff and community members from the building, which resulted in multiple injuries and arrests<ref name="heraldscotland.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/mobile/news/home-news/student-sit-in-after-police-eviction-celebrity-visits-more-protestors-and-an-upgrade-1.1092866|accessdate=31 March 2011|newspaper=Glasgow Herald}}</ref>.
+
A disused building at the [[University of Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] was occupied and re-opened as the [[Free Hetherington]] anti-cuts space. It has since attracted much controversy due to heavy-handed attempts to evict the students, staff and community members from the building, which resulted in multiple injuries and arrests.<ref name="heraldscotland.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/mobile/news/home-news/student-sit-in-after-police-eviction-celebrity-visits-more-protestors-and-an-upgrade-1.1092866|accessdate=31 March 2011|newspaper=Glasgow Herald}}</ref>
===12 February===
===12 February===
Line 46: Line 46:
===24 February===
===24 February===
â
A crucial Hull City Council meeting on 24 February was interrupted by protests.<ref>http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/news/Protesters-interrupt-crucial-council-budget-meeting/article-3266039-detail/article.html</ref> On the same day, a Sheffield City Council meeting was invaded by protesters.
+
A crucial Hull City Council meeting on 24 February was interrupted by protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/news/Protesters-interrupt-crucial-council-budget-meeting/article-3266039-detail/article.html |title=THE city council's budget meeting was adjourned at 5.25pm after protesters refused to leave the public gallery |publisher=Thisishullandeastriding.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> On the same day, a Sheffield City Council meeting was invaded by protesters.
===3 March===
===3 March===
â
On 3 March, the [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] and [[UK Uncut]] held a protest along [[Knightsbridge]] against tax evasion.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/414</ref>
+
On 3 March, the [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] and [[UK Uncut]] held a protest along [[Knightsbridge]] against tax evasion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/414 |title=London, Knightsbridge, Thu 3rd Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
â
A protest was also held on the same day by UK Uncut outside the [[Barclays]] bank in Victoria Square, [[Bolton]], opposite Bolton Town Hall. The protest was against tax evasion.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/395</ref>
+
A protest was also held on the same day by UK Uncut outside the [[Barclays]] bank in Victoria Square, [[Bolton]], opposite Bolton Town Hall. The protest was against tax evasion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/395 |title=Bolton, Thu 3rd Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===5 March===
===5 March===
â
On 5 March, there was a protest of around 2,000 people in Manchester about cuts being implemented on the city.<ref>http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1410046_2000_join_march_against_public_spending_cuts_in_manchester</ref>
+
On 5 March, there was a protest of around 2,000 people in Manchester about cuts being implemented on the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1410046_2000_join_march_against_public_spending_cuts_in_manchester |title=2,000 join march against public spending cuts in Manchester | Manchester Evening News |publisher=menmedia.co.uk |date=2011-03-05 |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
â
UK Uncut held protests in [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/428</ref>, [[Manchester]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/430</ref>, [[Liverpool]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/413</ref>, [[Leicester]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/422</ref>, [[Ipswich]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/423</ref>, [[Edinburgh]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/401</ref>, [[Colchester]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/426</ref>, [[Bristol]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/432</ref>, and [[Aberdeen]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/433</ref>. Protests in Perth were against the [[Scottish Liberal Democrats]] and tax evasion; protests in Manchester, Ipswich, and Aberdeen were anti-austerity in general; protests in Liverpool were against the [[Big Society]]; protests in Leicester and Colchester were against tax evasion and big bonuses for bankers; protests in Edinburgh were against the closure (by the government) of two nursery schools in the city, and tax evasion; and protests in Bristol were against the closure of a library in the city.
+
UK Uncut held protests in [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/428 |title=Perth, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Manchester]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/430 |title=Manchester, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Liverpool]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/413 |title=Liverpool, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Leicester]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/422 |title=Leicester, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Ipswich]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/423 |title=Ipswich, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Edinburgh]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/401 |title=Edinburgh, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Colchester]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/426 |title=Colchester, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Bristol]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/432 |title=Bristol, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> and [[Aberdeen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/433 |title=Aberdeen, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> Protests in Perth were against the [[Scottish Liberal Democrats]] and tax evasion; protests in Manchester, Ipswich, and Aberdeen were anti-austerity in general; protests in Liverpool were against the [[Big Society]]; protests in Leicester and Colchester were against tax evasion and big bonuses for bankers; protests in Edinburgh were against the closure (by the government) of two nursery schools in the city, and tax evasion; and protests in Bristol were against the closure of a library in the city.
===6 March===
===6 March===
â
UK Uncut held protests in [[Taunton]] against government cuts.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/403</ref>
+
UK Uncut held protests in [[Taunton]] against government cuts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/403 |title=Taunton, Sun 6th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===7 March===
===7 March===
â
UK Uncut held protests in the [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets]], mainly around the [[Canary Wharf]] area.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/438</ref> During the protests, a group of around 20 people occupied the foyer area of the [[One Churchill Place]] tower, HQ of [[Barclays]], while startled bankers were led out by more protesters and questioned.
+
UK Uncut held protests in the [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets]], mainly around the [[Canary Wharf]] area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/438 |title=London, Tower Hamlets, Mon 7th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> During the protests, a group of around 20 people occupied the foyer area of the [[One Churchill Place]] tower, HQ of [[Barclays]], while startled bankers were led out by more protesters and questioned.
===9 March===
===9 March===
â
UK Uncut held more protests on 9 March, in the [[London Borough of Bexley]]. They protested at the Bexley Council Budget Meeting that night.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/439</ref>
+
UK Uncut held more protests on 9 March, in the [[London Borough of Bexley]]. They protested at the Bexley Council Budget Meeting that night.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/439 |title=London, Bexley, Wed 9th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===11 March===
===11 March===
Line 73: Line 73:
On 12 March, 5,000 people marched from [[Devonshire Green]] to the venue, where one man was arrested for setting off a firework in a public space. Barricades were set up on [[Fargate]] and Surrey Street following several incidents,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-12722735 | work=BBC News | title=About 5,000 march in Lib Dem Sheffield conference protest | date=12 March 2011}}</ref> including a group of protesters running into a [[Topshop]] store on Fargate. A large group of protesters, separate from the main group, caused violence along the march, including trying (and failing) to set fire to a police car. This group declared the day as the ''Day of Rage''.
On 12 March, 5,000 people marched from [[Devonshire Green]] to the venue, where one man was arrested for setting off a firework in a public space. Barricades were set up on [[Fargate]] and Surrey Street following several incidents,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-12722735 | work=BBC News | title=About 5,000 march in Lib Dem Sheffield conference protest | date=12 March 2011}}</ref> including a group of protesters running into a [[Topshop]] store on Fargate. A large group of protesters, separate from the main group, caused violence along the march, including trying (and failing) to set fire to a police car. This group declared the day as the ''Day of Rage''.
â
Much smaller protests were held by UK Uncut in [[Ipswich]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/441</ref> and [[Poole]]<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/427</ref>.
+
Much smaller protests were held by UK Uncut in [[Ipswich]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/441 |title=Ipswich, Sat 12th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> and [[Poole]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/427 |title=Poole, Sat 12th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===13 March===
===13 March===
Small protests occurred in Sheffield on March 13.
Small protests occurred in Sheffield on March 13.
â
UK Uncut planned protests in [[Leeds]], but they were cancelled due to [[rain]] and "a Facebook invite organisational cock-up".<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/417</ref>
+
UK Uncut planned protests in [[Leeds]], but they were cancelled due to [[rain]] and "a Facebook invite organisational cock-up".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/417 |title=Leeds, Sun 13th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===14 March===
===14 March===
â
UK Uncut held anti-cuts protests in [[Basildon]] on 14 March.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/431</ref>
+
UK Uncut held anti-cuts protests in [[Basildon]] on 14 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/431 |title=Basildon, Mon 14th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===19 March===
===19 March===
Line 87: Line 87:
===22 March===
===22 March===
â
Around 5,000 young people from Schools, Universities and Colleges across [[Scotland]] march through [[Edinburgh]] and rally at the [[Scottish Parliament]] against cuts to education. On the same day the University of Glasgow management evicted the [[Free Hetherington]] occupation. The occupation then moved to the University Senate, before the occupiers were eventually offered their original location back, this offer was accepted<ref name="heraldscotland.com"/>.
+
Around 5,000 young people from Schools, Universities and Colleges across [[Scotland]] march through [[Edinburgh]] and rally at the [[Scottish Parliament]] against cuts to education. On the same day the University of Glasgow management evicted the [[Free Hetherington]] occupation. The occupation then moved to the University Senate, before the occupiers were eventually offered their original location back, this offer was accepted.<ref name="heraldscotland.com"/>
===25 March===
===25 March===
â
Protesters preparing ahead of the 26 March protests broke into 61 Curzon Street in London and occupied the building, calling it a "meeting place".<ref>http://www.demotix.com/news/636015/61-curzon-street-occupied-centre-march-26th-protests</ref>
+
Protesters preparing ahead of the 26 March protests broke into 61 Curzon Street in London and occupied the building, calling it a "meeting place".<ref>{{cite web|last=Milan |first=Alex |url=http://www.demotix.com/news/636015/61-curzon-street-occupied-centre-march-26th-protests |title=61 Curzon Street occupied as Centre for March 26th Protests |publisher=Demotix.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===26 March - "March for the Alternative"===
===26 March - "March for the Alternative"===
Line 101: Line 101:
[[File:March-for-the-alternative-007.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters at the March for the Alternative.]]
[[File:March-for-the-alternative-007.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters at the March for the Alternative.]]
â
For [[26 March]] the protests, the [[Trades Union Congress]] (TUC) estimated that over 100,000 people would attend a event in [[London]] that day. The police stated that the TUC were "very professional, very well prepared" with the march.<ref name="Townsend 2011.">[[#Tow11|Townsend et al 2011]].</ref> The TUC have urged protesters to keep peace, but several have threatened to riot and occupy buildings.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12864353 | work=BBC News | title=Anti-cuts march: Tens of thousands at London protest | date=27 March 2011}}</ref><ref>http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23935598-extremists-vow-to-hijack-march-and-bring-chaos-to-the-streets.do</ref> The demonstrations included a variety of participating organizations, such as the Lewisham Pensioners' Forum and the Latin American Women's Rights Service for example.<ref name=live/>
+
For [[26 March]] the protests, the [[Trades Union Congress]] (TUC) estimated that over 100,000 people would attend a event in [[London]] that day. The police stated that the TUC were "very professional, very well prepared" with the march.<ref name="Townsend 2011.">[[#Tow11|Townsend et al 2011]].</ref> The TUC have urged protesters to keep peace, but several have threatened to riot and occupy buildings.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12864353 | work=BBC News | title=Anti-cuts march: Tens of thousands at London protest | date=27 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23935598-extremists-vow-to-hijack-march-and-bring-chaos-to-the-streets.do |title=Extremists vow to hijack march and bring chaos to the streets | News |publisher=Thisislondon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> The demonstrations included a variety of participating organizations, such as the Lewisham Pensioners' Forum and the Latin American Women's Rights Service for example.<ref name=live/>
The TUC argued that the spending cuts were entirely unnecessary, being a product of the government's right wing ideology rather than actual need. Starting at [[Thames Embankment]], the protest march led down to [[Hyde Park]], where a rally took place, with the TUC general secretary [[Brendan Barber]] and [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] leader [[Ed Milliband]] addressing the assembled crowds. Several independent protesting groups moved from the main TUC march further north into [[Soho]] and [[Oxford Street]], where some committed acts of vandalism and got into clashes with riot police. Their actions were denounced by both the [[Metropolitan Police]] and the trade unionists responsible for organising the main march.
The TUC argued that the spending cuts were entirely unnecessary, being a product of the government's right wing ideology rather than actual need. Starting at [[Thames Embankment]], the protest march led down to [[Hyde Park]], where a rally took place, with the TUC general secretary [[Brendan Barber]] and [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] leader [[Ed Milliband]] addressing the assembled crowds. Several independent protesting groups moved from the main TUC march further north into [[Soho]] and [[Oxford Street]], where some committed acts of vandalism and got into clashes with riot police. Their actions were denounced by both the [[Metropolitan Police]] and the trade unionists responsible for organising the main march.
Line 121: Line 121:
===28 March===
===28 March===
â
On 28 March, around 400 people protested outside the Saltend Chemicals Plant in [[Kingston upon Hull | Hull]], after they were made redundant by the company.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-humber-12817734 | work=BBC News | title=Hull plant workers protest as contracts are terminated | date=22 March 2011}}</ref> A further 1000 people marched through Hull City Centre.<ref>http://www.humberbusiness.com/hull/1-000-protestors-march-Hull-city-centre/article-3379200-detail/article.html</ref>
+
On 28 March, around 400 people protested outside the Saltend Chemicals Plant in [[Kingston upon Hull | Hull]], after they were made redundant by the company.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-humber-12817734 | work=BBC News | title=Hull plant workers protest as contracts are terminated | date=22 March 2011}}</ref> A further 1000 people marched through Hull City Centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humberbusiness.com/hull/1-000-protestors-march-Hull-city-centre/article-3379200-detail/article.html |title=1,000 protestors to march in Hull city centre â warning to motorists |publisher=Humberbusiness.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===30 March===
===30 March===
Line 127: Line 127:
===1 April - "All Together for the NHS"===
===1 April - "All Together for the NHS"===
â
A major campaign called "All Together for the [[NHS]]" has been planned by False Economy on 1 April<ref>http://falseeconomy.org.uk/nhs</ref>. MPs are to be lobbied by NHS staff and usersand there will be campaigns to support the NHS all over the country.
+
A major campaign called "All Together for the [[NHS]]" has been planned by False Economy on 1 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://falseeconomy.org.uk/nhs |title=All Together for the NHS |publisher=False Economy |date=2011-04-01 |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> MPs are to be lobbied by NHS staff and usersand there will be campaigns to support the NHS all over the country.
===2 April===
===2 April===
â
A march and rally has been planned by UK Uncut for [[Bangor, Gwynedd|Bangor]] on 2 April.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/348</ref>
+
A march and rally has been planned by UK Uncut for [[Bangor, Gwynedd|Bangor]] on 2 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/348 |title=Bangor (Gwynedd), Sat 2nd Apr 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
â
Another march is going to go ahead in [[Edinburgh]].<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/455</ref>
+
Another march is going to go ahead in [[Edinburgh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/455 |title=Edinburgh, Sat 2nd Apr 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
â
A march was also later planned for [[Bristol]]. However, the authenticity of this action has not yet been verified. A peaceful protest will be held outside New Bridewell police station in solidarity and support of the peaceful UK Uncut protesters who were arrested on 26 March in the March for the Alternative. The planned meeting place is outside Bristol Hippodrome, and they will march to Rupert Street where the police station is situated.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/489</ref>
+
A march was also later planned for [[Bristol]]. However, the authenticity of this action has not yet been verified. A peaceful protest will be held outside New Bridewell police station in solidarity and support of the peaceful UK Uncut protesters who were arrested on 26 March in the March for the Alternative. The planned meeting place is outside Bristol Hippodrome, and they will march to Rupert Street where the police station is situated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/489 |title=Bristol, Sat 2nd Apr 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===5 April===
===5 April===
â
UK Uncut have planned a 'tour-style' protest at [[Canary Wharf]], [[London]], for this date, though it is yet to be confirmed whether it will go ahead.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/490</ref>
+
UK Uncut have planned a 'tour-style' protest at [[Canary Wharf]], [[London]], for this date, though it is yet to be confirmed whether it will go ahead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/490 |title=Canary Wharf, London, Tue 5th Apr 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===23 April===
===23 April===
â
UK Uncut are planning a protest outside the [[Royal Hallamshire Hospital]] on Glossop Road, [[Sheffield]],<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/487</ref> on 23 April. The protesters will meet outside the hospital, before marching north-east along Glossop Road, before going onto West End Road and finishing at the end of that road.
+
UK Uncut are planning a protest outside the [[Royal Hallamshire Hospital]] on Glossop Road, [[Sheffield]],<ref>[http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/487 ]{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref> on 23 April. The protesters will meet outside the hospital, before marching north-east along Glossop Road, before going onto West End Road and finishing at the end of that road.
===30 April===
===30 April===
â
UK Uncut are planning a protest in [[Leeds]] on 30 April, including the occupation of a building in the city.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/488</ref>
+
UK Uncut are planning a protest in [[Leeds]] on 30 April, including the occupation of a building in the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/488 |title=Leeds, Sat 30th Apr 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
===1 May===
===1 May===
â
Another protest by UK Uncut may go ahead in [[Oxford]] on 1 May.<ref>http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/486</ref>
+
Another protest by UK Uncut may go ahead in [[Oxford]] on 1 May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/486 |title=Oxford, Sun 1st May 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref>
==Public opinion==
==Public opinion==
Line 156: Line 156:
[[Daniel Hannan]], a journalist and the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] for [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England]], stated that the protesters "have decided to indulge their penchant for empty, futile, self-righteous indignation." He wrote, "After âNo Cuts!â the marchersâ favourite slogan was âFairness!â Alright, then... How about being fair to our children, whom we have freighted with a debt unprecedented in peacetime?"<ref>{{citenews|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/danielhannan/100081436/march-for-the-alternative-what-alternative/|title='March for the Alternative'? WHAT alternative?|author=[[Daniel Hannan]]|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''}}</ref>
[[Daniel Hannan]], a journalist and the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] for [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England]], stated that the protesters "have decided to indulge their penchant for empty, futile, self-righteous indignation." He wrote, "After âNo Cuts!â the marchersâ favourite slogan was âFairness!â Alright, then... How about being fair to our children, whom we have freighted with a debt unprecedented in peacetime?"<ref>{{citenews|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/danielhannan/100081436/march-for-the-alternative-what-alternative/|title='March for the Alternative'? WHAT alternative?|author=[[Daniel Hannan]]|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''}}</ref>
â
[[Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Nick Clegg]] told [[Reuters]] news service, "If I was a demonstrator in London, I would be furious with the Labour leadership, because they are whipping up people's fervour and they are being utterly dishonest... We have an opposition party that has retreated into the worst kind of infantile opposition politics, which is to score lots of tactical points and not level with people about what they would do instead."<ref name=clegg>{{citenews|title=Clegg says Labour dishonestly stoking cuts protest|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/26/uk-britain-protests-clegg-idUKTRE72P0AZ20110326|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
+
[[Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Nick Clegg]] told [[Reuters]] news service, "If I was a demonstrator in London, I would be furious with the Labour leadership, because they are whipping up people's fervour and they are being utterly dishonest... We have an opposition party that has retreated into the worst kind of infantile opposition politics, which is to score lots of tactical points and not level with people about what they would do instead."<ref name=clegg>{{citenews|title=Clegg says Labour dishonestly stoking cuts protest|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/26/uk-britain-protests-clegg-idUKTRE72P0AZ20110326|publisher=Reuters|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
